derivation.yuyuan_name: Old English, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zwaan and German Schwan. The current sense of the verb originated as military slang, referring to the free movement of armoured vehicles

entry.def: A swan is a large bird with a very long neck. Swans live on rivers and lakes and are usually white.
If you describe someone as swanning around or swanning off, you mean that they go and have fun, rather than working or taking care of their responsibilities.

example.ex: She spends her time swanning around the world...
example.tran: 她一个人自由自在地环游世界。

example.ex: The mother was widowed and had swanned off.
example.tran: 这位母亲成了寡妇，已经悠然闲逛去了。

means.word_mean: 1. stately heavy-bodied aquatic bird with very long neck and usually white plumage as adult
1. to declare or affirm solemnly and formally as true;

sentences.sentence: "Before God I swear I am innocent"

means.word_mean: 2. move about aimlessly or without any destination, often in search of food or employment;

sentences.en: Stop swanning about pretending to be clever.
She’s swanning around Europe for the summer.
He’s always swanning off to Spain on holiday!
sentences.cn: 他一有假期就去西班牙悠闲作乐！
